Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports, past detention records, extortion incidents
Basis_of_Claim: Perceived association with LTTE, government harassment, multiple detentions, extortion
Evaluation_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Incidents not linked to Convention grounds, no systematic persecution, LTTE extortion tied to general country conditions
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection claim hearing, followed by judicial review
Application_Error: Alleged error in assessing persecution and future risk
Review_Outcome: No reviewable error found; Board's decision upheld
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Application_Factor: Past incidents considered insufficient to establish future risk
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Decision_Review_Issue: Existence of persecution on Convention grounds, credibility of risk
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention; IRPA s. 96-98
Cause_of_Refusal: No well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds; incidents classified as harassment, not persecution
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence linking harm to Convention grounds
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge to Boardâ€™s interpretation of persecution and risk assessment
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review applicable to Board decisions
